title.rendered: Two men could go to jail for 20 years for scamming people with NFTs

content.rendered:
Again a scam related to NFT’s. And how many are there? How far will people be fooled by these things? But hey, at least, in this case, justice will be done: two men could go to jail for up to 20 years. I hope they get them inside and throw away the key.

The two men were charged with conspiracy to commit fraud electronic and money laundering after they made $1.1 million from a non-fungible token project before abandoning it without fulfilling any of the promises they made and leaving buyers with nothing in return for their investments.

The United States Department of Justice accuses Ethan Nguyen Y Andre Lacuna20 years old, for the alleged management of the project NFT Frostieswhich saw its 8,888 NFTs, each priced at about $180, sell out by the time of its public launch.

🚨Breaking🚨

Frosties NFT Project rugpulled, causes millions in losses to the investors ❌

This is the first known NFT scam of the year. Investors have reportedly lost $1.3 million🤯#Whalecointalk #CryptocurrencyNews #Rugpull #Frosties #Opensea pic.twitter.com/17jNb4rX8Q

— Whale Coin Talk 🐳 (@WhaleCoinTalk) January 13, 2022

What was the scam based on NFTs that were sold through Discord

Like other similar NFT collections, buyers were promised rewards like a “metaverse” game, gifts, 3D versions of their avatars, etc. There was also the possibility of making a lot of money by reselling their NFTs at a higher price.

But shortly after the initial sale, all traces of the Frosties project disappeared from the internet, including the Discord server, and buyers found that they could only get a few dollars from the sale of their NFTs.

The criminal complaint against the couple includes as evidence of the crime what appears to be an apology from Nguyen to one of the mods on the server. “I know this is shocking, but this project is coming to an end. I never intended to keep the project going, and I have no plan for anything in the future,” she reads. The mod was also sent some Ethereum for its troubles, and Nguyen recommended that it delete its Discord account to avoid the heat of the project’s angry investors.

Prosecutors say Nguyen and Llacuna transferred about $1.1 million in cryptocurrency they got from the hoax to various wallets in multiple transactions designed to hide the origin of the funds.

Luckily, they were caught and now the full weight of the law will fall on them

That’s where the story usually ends, but it seems the pair were emboldened by their success. They prepared a series of NFTs called embers which was supposed to be released in March. There was even a roadmap promising that $50,000 would be donated to the Red Cross, which the charity says it did receive, with 25% of the funds collected going into a community-controlled wallet. Investigators say this would have been another “rug-pulling” scheme and he could have made an extra $1.5 million.

The Verge commented that researchers were able to match data from Nguyen and Llacuna’s Discord accounts, including the former’s IP address and the latter’s email address and phone number, with the corresponding accounts on Coinbase. These cryptocurrency exchange accounts were linked to a Citibank credit card and a government ID that allowed authorities to track them down, and both men now face charges of up to 20 years in prison.

So hey, there was a happy ending after all. The most ironic thing is that if they are found guilty, they may end up “minting” car licenses in some state prison. That would be poetic justice. Still, always keep in mind with these things related to NFTs, that there is a 90% chance that the “project” they are trying to sell you is a scam. Be careful.

And you, what do you think of NFTs? Would they be fooled by something so obvious?
